problem.tex: Let $f(z)=\frac{e^z}{(z-\pi i)^6}$ and let $\gamma$ be the counter-clockwise boundary of the square $x,y=\pm4$. Evaluate $\int_\gamma f(z)dz$.

solution.tex: $f$ is a meromorphic function with a single pole at $z=\pi i$. This pole is inside the region encircled by $\gamma$, so we will apply Cauchy's integral formula. Note that Cauchy's integral theorem means that the integral will be the same over any curve which encircles $\pi i$ once in the positive direction, so we don't need to worry about the fact that $\gamma$ is a square. First recall Cauchy's integral formula for a holomorphic function $g$: \[g^{(n)}(z)=\frac{n!}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{g(w)}{(w-z)^{n+1}}dw.\] Setting $n=5$, $z=\pi i$, and $g(z)=e^z$ gives \[e^{(5)}(\pi i)=\frac{5!}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma\frac{e^w}{(w-\pi i)^6}dw.\] This we can calculate, \[\int_\gamma\frac{e^w}{(w-\pi i)^6}dw=\frac{2\pi i}{5!}e^{\pi i}=-\frac{2\pi i}{5!}.\]
